awd_titl_txt: Effects of ADVANCE in the STEM Disciplines: Faculty Diversity, Women in Leadership, and Institutional Transformation
awd_abstract_narration:
Frank Dobbins, of Harvard University, proposes a three-year project to conduct and analyze a survey of diversity policies and equity program reforms at 1,000 universities in the United States between 1990 and 2014.  Building upon work that he and his collaborators conducted on the effectiveness of diversity programs at corporations in the United States, they develop several new survey instruments to conduct a research evaluation of diversity programming at universities in the United States.  In particular, they will assess the impact of policies and programs to promote diversity and equity on individual faculty members as well as on the institutions themselves.  These kinds of programs include mentoring activities, networking, professional development activities, career life balances policies and other policy changes. They further compare equity outcomes for individuals and at the institutional level at institutions that have received funding from the National Science Foundation to promote gender equity, awards from the ADVANCE program.  They will use data from the National Science Foundation Survey of Doctorate Recipients and the Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System as well as collect new data from the institutions themselves.  Using these databases, the PI and his team will conduct a quantitative study to assess the effects of equity reforms, the persistence of equity reforms, and the diffusion of such reforms across types of institutions.  Findings from this research has the potential to dramatically change the ways that universities in the United States address issues of gender equity because the study should result in identifying policies and programs that are most effective at achieving equity.

The PI team will use a multi-level modeling methodology incorporating the data that they collect through the new surveys with the big data sets already available to them to fulfill the goals discussed above.  In their research on corporate equity programs the Principal Investigators developed an evidence-based theory of the remediation of inequality built on four insights from sociology and social psychology.  They will test those theoretical premises in the academic context.  They incorporate insights from the work-autonomy and self-determination literatures, the labeling and self-determination theories, feminist theory, and accountability theory to build the models to test theories on how equity may be achieved in university settings.  Testing these theories will advance research on gender inequality in academia and at work more generally.  This will be the first study to utilize comprehensive longitudinal data from ADVANCE and peer institutions to evaluate the impact of diversity and equity programming.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: PRESIDENT AND FELLOWS OF HARVARD COLLEGE

por.por_cntn:
This project was set up to evaluate the results of programs adopted to equalize career opportunities for all faculty, which have been widely adopted by U.S. colleges and universities. Among these programs are NSF-funded ADVANCE Institutional Transformation programs at participating colleges and universities.

The project included building an original retrospective database covering the hiring, promotion, diversity, and work-life practices at over 600 colleges and universities between 1992 and 2016. These data were merged with data from Integrated Postsecondary Education Systems (IPEDS) on the surveyed schools' faculty and student composition, by race/ethnicity and gender, as well as job type, and with data on the demographics and careers of individual faculty members working in these schools, from the Survey of Doctorate Recipients.  

Analyses of these data allowed for testing theories of the remediation of inequality developed by the CO-PIs' earlier work on corporate diversity measures. We found that the same principles that shape the success or failure of diversity innovation in the corporate world are at work in colleges and universities as well. First, the work-autonomy and self-determination literatures suggest that organization members are mobilized to support new goals by reforms that engage them as planners and leaders of change.  We have found that programs that create faculty engagement, such as targeted recruitment of women faculty and faculty of color, mentoring programs, especially those that target women and people of color, and diversity taskforces, lead to significant increases in the share of women and people of color among tenured faculty.

Second, labeling and self-determination theories suggest that reforms that label members of an organization in negative ways will backfire. Our analyses have shown that diversity training programs, which single out faculty members as the culprits of inequality, and discrimination grievance procedures, which threaten to punish faculty members for discrimination of harassment, do not lead to increases in faculty diversity and at times lead to reductions in diversity.

Third, feminist theory suggests that reforms designed to normalize the lived experiences of women as well as men, including work-life initiatives, will promote gender equity.  In support of this theoretical insight, we have found that universal tenure clock extensions – those that are open to both men and women and are granted automatically - are more effective in promoting gender diversity among tenured faculty than tenure clock extensions that are available only to women and require opting in. These findings are especially strong for women of color, who also experience greater boundaries at work and work-life challenges.

Finally, accountability theory suggests that creating awareness of problems will encourage members to censor their own biases and actively implement equity reforms. We have found that climate surveys and equity studies, as well as diversity offices and staff, lead to significant increases in tenured faculty diversity. Testing theories of remediation of inequality makes significant advances to research on gender inequality in academia and at work more generally.

We have also found that despite progress on faculty diversity, women and people of color remain vulnerable in times of crisis. We have shown that universities and colleges in the U.S. have experienced significant declines in the hiring of women faculty and faculty of color during and after the 2008 Great Recession, declines that did not reverse until 2015.

Understanding how to effectively increase diversity among tenured faculty in U.S. colleges and universities is important not only for the careers of those faculty but also for the retention, and success, of women students and students of color.  By attracting and retaining women faculty and faculty from all race and ethnic groups, the United States can ensure the best use of academic talent, the best education for a diverse student body, and continued leadership in STEM fields.  U.S. higher education institutions and grant-givers have invested many resources in diversity and work life programs. Yet women and people of color remain significantly underrepresented. Our findings in this research about what works and what doesn't in achieving faculty diversity carry the promise to guide university leaders in making decisions about which diversity innovations to put in place and what to look for when considering their effects.
